author: Bill in Michigan

review: At less than a hundred bucks, I decided to push the buy button after thinking about it for a couple of generational iterations. I watch a lot of TV, but seldom sports programming. I don't often rent a movie and certainly don't buy or collect DVDs, don't go to the theater often. So why do I even need this? I don't. The Apple TV is a Wi-Fi connected gateway to other web portals like Netflix, Hulu Plus, Go HBO, and Apple store most of which seem to require rental fees or paid subscriptions to get content. So beyond the hundred bucks you pay for this Wi-Fi peripheral you have to really want the content to pay extra to these providers in addition to already having working, Wi-Fi and cable or other internet connection services (which are utility subscriptions as well). Can you tell I am not a fan of the subscription payment model? Anyway, Apple TV will allow me to stream iTunes music content from my 2007 model iMac to my music system on a different floor of my home. The iMac has to be awake and iTunes running, however. Also useful, I can mirror my iPad 2 (won't work with the iPad1) and control Apple TV from it using Apple Remote app, and some apps and web sites can access Apple TV directly from the iPad. I can also display anything in my photo library on the iMac or iPad on the HDTV screen and associated surround sound system. Video and display mirroring from the iMac is limited to models 2011 and newer, very sad, but I knew that going in. I found it desirable to bump my cable internet speed from 1.5 Mbs (that's bits not bytes, by the way) to 5 Mbs another $5/mo, since some trailers and other content took a long time to load. This helped, but I think I would need even faster and more costly speed for some streaming HD content to be viewed without breaks. There is a lot of nickle and dime (read $5 and $10) added costs to getting the most out of this device. That sticks in the craw of this thrifty but honest reviewer.

review: The setup was easy and the Apple TV works well with Netflix. However, I already had no less than ten devices (four computers, one tablet, two smart phones, one game console, and two DVD players which worked well with Netflix. I primarily bought this for "home sharing" and to see what else it was capable of. Well, it has few other capabilities that are of more than passing curiosities to me, and the home sharing works horribly. I just spent about a half-hour getting the Apple TV to play a movie through home sharing. Five minutes into the movie, it stopped and displayed the message "To access your iTunes library on Apple TV, turn on Home Sharing in iTunes on your computer." Obviously, "home sharing" is already turned on. Another ten minutes of tinkering and (hopefully) I'll be able to watch my movie. This problem didn't seem to occur when I first bought the Apple TV two months ago, but it seems to occur every time now. Extremely frustrating. If you want to access a streaming service like Netflix, the best solution is to connect a computer directly to your TV. You should also be able to access multimedia files directly from your home network, without the added hassle of iTunes. The simplest solution fr streaming is a DVD player, which would be far more functional than Apple TV at only two-thirds the price.
